author: deepfield67
body: So, I'm new to all this, just started last week by opening a Fidelity account. I previously had like 10k in checking, basically, and I'm slowly putting it into a few Fidelity mutual funds (FBALX and FXNAX). I bought a little PHO and SMH just to see how the whole process works and they looked kinda promising but they aren't really part of my plan, more like an experiment. Then later when I'm more familiar with the whole thing and they look like they're doing well, I can always focus more on them. But my main plan for investing/saving are these two Fidelity funds. I guess my question is: am I doing something stupid that just isn't apparent to me, being new? These two funds seem to cover a lot, so I'm pretty diversified between them. In fact there seems to be a little overlap, but that's probably OK? Also, is there any major reason to go with Fidelity vs Vanguard for funds like this? Aside from some apparently minor differences, they look to operate about the same, dare similar allocations, etc. I just hate being new, I need someone to tell me I'm not making horrible decisions. (Or that I am). Lol, thanks in advance!

author: greytoc
body:
Is there a reason why you allocated both FBALX and FXNAX? The reason to select a balance fund like FBALX is because there is already a bond allocation as part of that fund. The only reason to also hold FXNAX is if you are intending to over-weight your portfolio with fixed income which may be fine depending on your goals, risk tolerance, financial situation, and age to retirement. 

As a Fidelity customer - you will also have access to funds which are reduced in expense such as their Zero funds.  

And if you are seeking for something simpler as you learn to understand - Fidelity has a bunch of target date funds which they call their Freedom funds. [https://www.fidelity.com/mutual-funds/fidelity-fund-portfolios/freedom-funds](https://www.fidelity.com/mutual-funds/fidelity-fund-portfolios/freedom-funds)

author: Necessary-Shallot976
body:
Exactly, you just buy CFVI from your broker (Fidelity, Ameritrade  etc.), just like any other stock. A SPAC (CFVI) can only combine with a single entity (that's why it's called an initial business combination vs. combinations) - in this case, they are combining with Rumble, so that's what you're going to get once the conversion is final (i.e. your CFVI shares will disappear and get replaced with Rumble ones). Unless the deal falls through (it is very rare, but it can happen - the Perishing Square SPAC is a good example), you will end up with Rumble shares in 2022.

A word of advice (which you are free to ignore) from someone who has been investing for 20+ years: do a little bit of research on how SPACs work, even if it's a 10 min video. You're about to put hard earned money into something you don't understand the risks of. A 'sure thing' can end up blowing up 37 different ways - if nothing else, at least you will have learned something useful. Hope this goes your way!

author: greytoc
body:
Welcome to r/investing. 

A couple of things - don't be gullible and fall victim to conspiracy theories. Most of the stuff about hedge funds have zero basis in reality. 

Investing in the stock market isn't done through an app. It's a regulated financial transaction which is performed through a registered broker-dealer. That broker-dealer may offer an app to access their services. 

You should choose your broker-dealer first based on their services and merits before ever deciding if you want to use their app. 

If you already have a banking relationship - you can start there and see if your bank has a broker-dealer subsidiary. For example - Bank of America owns MerrillEdge. 

Since you have a 401k - is the 401k being administered by a broker-dealer like a Fidelity? That's another place to look to open your brokerage account.

The larger and more established retail broker-dealers are normally the ones to consider if you are new and unsure of the services that you need. For example - Fidelity, Vanguard, Merrill Edge, TD Admeritrade/Schwab, etc. 

Lastly - make sure you understand the taxable benefits of considering IRA's and ROTH brokerage accounts first before opening a taxable brokerage account. See the Wiki on the top of this post for links to resources. Also - see the r/personalfinance wiki for things to consider before you invest other income.

author: Neakhanie
body:
Use Fidelity. It has charts and graphs showing everything you need, IMHO. A broad ETF like SPY or QQQ is considered both sophisticated and suitable for a new person who is not investing his rent money. Not individual stocks, unless you have a trust fund, or enjoy humorously posting your horrendous losses to the group. Yes, go ahead and do partial shares if a full share is not convenient to buy.  
Before you invest in either SPY or QQQ, Google “S&P 500 Historical Annual Returns”. See the lines going down? Make sure you’re ok with that. Some years, Not only are there no profits for an entire year, there are also losses. Over 5-10-20 years, it’s your best bet statistically, but only if you hang on to it.  
Remember “Time in the market beats timing the market every time”.

author: greytoc
body:
Looks like you are in decent shape. The allocation looks good imo - especially for someone newer to investing. 

You mentioned you have a high risk tolerance. Tolerance level descriptions can be subjective so.... But you could consider allocating 5% in an actively managed growth fund as well. Fidelity offers large and mid-cap growth funds.

And if you wanted some higher risk options - you can allocate 1% to crypto ETNs like $ethe and $gdlc. 

As others mentioned - you would likely want to rebalance at least annually. I usually do it twice a year. And as your risk tolerate changes - then consider reallocating to include fixed income funds as you get closer to retirement.
